oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of an exotic parasitoid on Plutella xylostella (Lepidoptera: Plutellidae) population dynamics, damage and indigenous natural enemies in Kenya.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: B, Löhr
R, Gathu
C, Kariuki
J, Obiero
G, Gichini
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: theme:invasion impact
Kenya
Plutella xylostella
invasion biology
invasive species
Lepidoptera
population dynamics
Plutellidae
invasion impact
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>Diadegma semiclausum</jats:italic> (Hellén) (Hymenoptera: lchneumonidae), an exotic diamondback moth parasitoid, was released in two pilot areas (Werugha in Coast Region and Tharuni in Central Province) in Kenya. Fifteen month before release, observations on the diamondback moth, <jats:italic>Plutella xylostella</jats:italic> (Linnaeus), and local natural enemy population dynamics and pest damage were initiated in both areas and continued for three years after release. The <jats:italic>P. xylostella</jats:italic> population was bimodal with higher records during dry seasons. At Werugha, the peak population of <jats:italic>P. xylostella</jats:italic> was 16.8 per plant (October 2001); at Tharuni it was 12.8 (February 2002). Populations at Werugha declined from three months after release and decreased from 5.4 per plant (before release) to 0.8 (year 3 after release). Concurrently, average damage (1.9 to 1.5) (on a 0–5 scale), proportion of attacked plants (72 to 31%) and proportion of plants in damage group >2 (plants with head damage) decreased (21.4 to 5.3%), while total parasitism increased from 14.4 (before) to 52.5% (year 3 after release, 90% due to <jats:italic>D. semiclausum</jats:italic>). At Tharuni, <jats:italic>D. semiclausum</jats:italic> was only recovered 3 months after release. Average populations of <jats:italic>P. xylostella</jats:italic> declined from 5.9 per plant (before release) to 2.4 (year 3 after release) and damage scores from 2.3 to 1.7. The proportion of plants in damage group >2 declined from 39.7 to 4.5% while overall parasitism increased from 4.2 to 40.6% (98.3% by <jats:italic>D. semiclausum</jats:italic>). Four species of indigenous parasitoids (<jats:italic>Diadegma mollipla</jats:italic> (Holmgren), <jats:italic>Oomyzus sokolowskii</jats:italic> (Kurdjumov)<jats:italic>, Apanteles</jats:italic> sp. and <jats:italic>Itoplectis</jats:italic> sp., all primary parasitoids) were almost completely displaced by <jats:italic>D. semiclausum</jats:italic>. Possible reasons for the different parasitoid development between the two release areas and the displacement of the indigenous species are discussed.</jats:p>
